Dispute_Type: Administrative law dispute over regulatory authority and Indigenous consultation
Legal_Issue: Whether the Crown had a duty to consult the KAFN regarding aquaculture licenses
Governing_Law: Crown's duty to consult doctrine under Canadian Aboriginal law
Evidence_Assessment: Court reviewed evidence of DFO's 22-month consultation efforts with First Nations
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (KAFN) to demonstrate inadequate consultation
Credibility_Factor: DFO's documented engagement and regulatory development post-Morton decision
Legal_Rule: The Crown's duty to consult arises when it has knowledge of potential Aboriginal rights and contemplates conduct that might adversely affect them
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of consultation process prior to license issuance
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure of DFO to adequately consult KAFN on aquaculture licensing
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed; duty to consult was fulfilled
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Consultation conducted over 22 months with transitional licensing in place
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and extent of DFO consultations, regulatory development timeline
Legal_Framework: Aboriginal rights protection under Section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982
Applicant_Challenge: Inadequate consultation by DFO on aquaculture licenses affecting potential Aboriginal rights
Legal_Rule_Source: Supreme Court of Canada jurisprudence on duty to consult
Defendant_Response: DFO demonstrated reasonable consultation efforts over 22 months
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of consultation records, regulatory actions
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of aquaculture license issuance
Outcome: No remedy granted; DFO's actions found lawful
Remedy_Sought: Set aside of aquaculture licenses or declaration of inadequate consultation
Authority: Department of Fisheries and Oceans (DFO), Canada
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to fulfill duty to consult on potential Aboriginal rights
Applicable_Process: Post-Morton transition of aquaculture regulation to federal jurisdiction
Outcome_of_Review: Duty to consult was satisfied; no legal error found
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction over fisheries and aquaculture post-regulatory transfer
Governing_Rule: Duty to consult, accommodate, and potentially compensate framework
